reviews.review_text:
Globally, I was very satisfied with Bluehost. Support: So far, I have not seen such a great customer support. People on lie support were very helpful even though I'm a beginner, and they gave me basic advice on what I should accomplish even when I decided to change host (reasons later).
Uptime and speed: I did not notice any issue with this aspect of hosting. My website isn't a behemoth, though, so I can't testify so much on that part. Value: As a renewing customer, I was a bit disappointed by the price they offered me for a 3 years hosting.
I was seeing better offers elsewhere (and even for Bluehost NEW customers) so I decided to leave. The customer support did try to find a way to keep me, but it was not enough. Globally, if you're ok with the price, go all in. They're great!

I've been a BlueHost subscriber for the past 3 years and have had an excellent experience through them. When I first subscribed it was a matter of pricing->feature value, but the cPanel experience was weak and the upgrade process was hit and miss. Over the past three years BlueHost has resolved any issues I had with them.
They're cPanel is greatly improved, they're feature set is much broader with few limitations, and with their new reseller account options I can host clients without any of the problems I used to run in to. BlueHost's cPanel in particular is where the best value comes. When I started my subscription with them I was less than savvy about many things relating to hosting or marketing or anything else that would otherwise lead to solid web presence.
There are many included tools and promotions that BlueHost provides with the subscription that put me on the right track and led to more opportunities as I matured. Technical expertise is not a requirement as BlueHost has most of those tools available to you, but there is still enough flexibility for more savvy developers to get their hands dirty. The only one quorum I have is a lack of root level access, but that isn't a dealbreaker for myself personally.
Overall I'd consider BlueHost as one of my favorite webhosts. There are others I've tried, but BlueHost has been the most reliable and their customer service team has always been quick and knowledgeable. For those who want a simple but reliable experience then BlueHost is the way to go; those who want complete control over their experience may not like how BlueHost does things.

Bluehost support is bad. Yes you have live chat but it's entirely outsourced to third-world countries and they are painfully slow at replying. As well, I upgraded from shared hosting package to cloud hosting and they did something wrong in the transition and my website went down.
I then had to create a ticket and it took 4 days to get an update on the ticket. As well, in terms of page speed, the "Server response time" is always above 1 second, which is way above the Google Page Speed recommended limit of 300ms, and this is with cloud hosting which is supposed to be fast. All in all, if you haven't chosen yet, don't choose bluehost.
The only reason I'm still with them right now is because it would be a pain the *** to move all my sites and contact with no downtime or seo hit. Stay away

Hi,
I have been using BlueHost for my Wordpress Site for the past two months. Earlier I was using NameCheap hosting and now I feel glad that I switched. Currently, I'm using the Basic Shared Hosting plan.
BlueHost's shared hosting is not only fast but reliable with good customer support. I am also using the Cloudflare CDN which BlueHost and it has really improved the site's loading speed.So far, my site has been down only for once and that was just a few days after I switched to BlueHost. However, their customer support was fast in responding to my issue and they got it resolved within half an hour.
Since then, I haven't faced any issues with my site. Another good thing about BlueHost is their Control Panel. It is easy to use and user-friendly.
Bluehost's control panel also provides additional services like SEO based services and CloudFlare integration. I'll definitely upgrade to better plans at Bluehost once my website begins to generate more traffic. For small site owners and bloggers, I'll definitely recommend BlueHost for their excellent services.

In the past it was a good hosting provider, but now it is a shame the low quality of service, the lack of knowledge of the support staff and do not refund your money when you decide to leave. I've been trying for weeks to get back more than 500 USD and they do not, it's a shame and a shame

This support is the worst ever! Support people don't even know their own system and don't want to help! Anything you ask from them they are not able to answer or they want to charge for everything.
I would not use them ever! They are useless.... Never use them! Stay away from them!

We bought a shared hosting for 3 years, the biggest mistake of my life. Value per money is the worst thing. Support was loading hours everytime I wanted to fix something.
Leaving from this hosting after 1 year, I know there is no refund policy for the rest of the 2 years it's lost money, but I hope people who read this feedback won't choose this company. Search before you choose.

I have been with Bluehost for several years. I always give their support team kudos. However, in the past year, their email is getting worse and worse.
Their servers are black listed and they don't do anything about it. They respond with "Try sending it again in an an hour when the servers rotate." This affects everyone in my business. We are working and with this kind of terrible service, we never know if your email goes through to a client or customer.
Their excuse is that email servers are shared so things like this happen. When I point out that email has been this way since before AOL and companies like AOL, gmail and others seem to deliver email just fine, the rep always seems to finally admit the senior management at Bluehost is not funding email support to force people to buy paid email services. IMO, email is a cost-of-doing-business type of feature.
Meaning if I buy a car, a steering wheel is a cost-of-doing-business feature. I have a car (Bluehost) and it used to have steering wheel one hundred percent of the time. Now, the steering wheel is only there 70 of the time while I am driving.
I then call the service department, they tell me it's not a safety risk. I should keep the car but get an Uber (Paid Gmail) to be able to get to work every day for reliability and safety. My answer is no thanks.
I just get any other car on the market, even one like GoDaddy which I hate, and get a working steering wheel. It reminds me of the old Lily Tomlin skit about the phone company. She would always say, We don't care.
We don't have to. We're the phone company. At least with hosting companies, there are many options.
It was nice while it lasted Bluehost. I have been patient trying to let you get your act together. Good luck.

Bluehost hosting service is the best service provider out there. If you do a search for web hosting providers they come up number one in each category and there is a reason for it. They are available 24 hours a day and money back guarantee was one of the reasons I picked them. I own a web development business named Cyber-Farms and the up time is critical.

I spent 139 (!) minutes on the phone yesterday trying to get them to map a domain to a subdirectory in our public_html directory. Something trivial that you can do yourself with other hosts like Dreamhost, mediatemple, pair, and so on. In the first few minutes, they messed up the existing path and then spent more than 2 hours telling me this is not possible and ended up leaving me having to migrate my site to the root on the server (where a dated site was located I had been trying to preserve).
I have worked with dozens (100's?) of hosts since I started web dev in 1996. This was THE worst I have experienced. Luckily I only have 3 clients with these ppl. Unreal.

I purchased a 3 year hosting plan from BlueHost on a Saturday. They assigned me a temporary domain name which support told me would last from 25 minutes to 5 hours. During this time I was able to access Wordpress and start putting the page for my blog together.
After 5 hours I contacted BlueHost live chat to ask how long it would take for my domain name to become active. The person on chat never seemed to understand my problem. I even copied and pasted the error message from their site that explained the situation but to no avail.
I couldn't see how my blog looked or access email while the domain remained with a temporary address. On Sunday I tried 2 more times with live chat but couldn't get my problem resolved. I tried again on Monday and after chatting for a few minutes I realized that I wasn't going to have my problem resolved and asked for a refund.
The person took my information and said that I would be getting my refund. The refund hadn't been posted to my credit card account on Tuesday so I called customer support and talked to a person who understood my original problem and offered to solve it. I said no, I would just like to get my refund.
They told me that I wouldn't be getting the refund for my domain name purchase because the person who was processing the refund on Monday didn't complete the process and it had been more than 3 days since I had purchased the domain name and they would only refund that purchase during the first 3 days. (By the way, Tuesday was 3 days after Saturday) I received an email detailing my refund (less the price paid for the domain name) on Tuesday but it hadn't been posted to my credit card on Wednesday. I filed a claim with the credit card company and they have issued me a provisional credit. I know that stuff happens but when a problem is brought to the attention of a support person the problem should be worked on.
The live chat people should have been able to solve my problem or pushed it up to someone who could. If you use BlueHost I would recommend that you use their phone support instead of live chat for even the most simple problems.

Well, overall I think the service is okay. I am an English teacher and I use Bluehost for my blog about writing. I use their WordPress hosting service and I am satisfied with the service, although there are some flaws.
Pros:
-Easy setup
-Very good uptime (all the time)
-Good speed
Cons:
-Support is not great
-The price is higher than other hosting
During my last semester of teaching I was approached by one of my students who said he could optimize my site and get many more readers quickly, but found some security flaws in the site which should be fixed first. He offered to fix it himself for free, but first I contacted support. They did not do much and claimed the site was in good standing with security.
They have their own "intrusion detection/prevention system" which stops their service from getting hacked, but I found out it doesn't actually protect my website. I reluctantly let the student fix my site after giving him my account details and he managed to find all kinds of flaws from the inside as well. He fixed most of them within a couple of days, from bad configuration, bad plugins, and hiding my personal email/account.
I'm not very good with this kind of stuff but was astonished by how much the student was able to do that BlueHost was not able to do. The student also showed me that there were much cheaper hosting plans I could have gotten, and sure enough he was right, so I don't think the value is great for this host. Other than all that, the first setup of the website was really easy, only a few clicks and it was ready. Everything went smoothly and although the site isn't super fast, it is up 100% of the time (or very close, I don't know what happens when I'm not on it.)
Overall I give this host somewhere between 3/4 stars.

I wanted to setup my company website, after comparing and reading reviews of many webhost, I finally found BlueHost, believe me I had the best experience with bluehost, their cpanel have all the features and helped me a lot to setup my website in just a single day, I found the web hosting price in my budget, I would really recommend bluehost for any web hosting needs.

Bluehost has a very nice list of features, and the best of them being the 'Unlimited Bandwidth" in a very low cost, cheaper than many others as of the quality of service that Bluehost provides, but what I don't like about the host is that they have a good customer service but some of their employees keep turning rude at some moments!

I'm using BlueHost Since last 2 to 3 Years, I found BlueHost to be reliable and customer friendly hosting service. Their 24/7 customer support is among the best.That’s why I love this Hosting Platform, and they give all time Something Amazing Like 150$ foAdvertisingnt oAdWordsds. I'm Happy and Feel always Free about my Hosting Issues. I'm using their Shared hosting Plan and Get Everything Unlimited.

This is best hosting company for law budget customer with Indian perspective. It delivers budget plans with offer on the occasion of the Independence day. It has a variety of CMS within the server.
It helps to make a good website within a minute. Good security with Linux based server. I give them 4.6 out of 5.

I registered my domain on Bluehost. I chose a monthly package which I think should deduct approx $10 monthly. I made sure that everything is good to go.
So when they processed my order, it showed that I selected an yearly package and they deducted $120 from my account. I contacted their support and they were not admitting at first after I showed them screenshot of my order, They agreed to give me my refund but they agreed to give only $60 so I decided to use the hosting.

I have been using Bluehost for almost a year or so, it was so tough for me, to get started my blogging career with hosting issues. I was using a local hosting company before, with no support and which was in the dark. I don't know, what other reliable option available out there, but I was left alone, although the company was closed because of their problems.
Bluehost packages are so accurate that they're made by, keeping the exact requirements of a site owner, in mind. They are very optimized regarding pricing, features, and security. They know and they've best and exact solution at the correct time.
I would recommend others for this particular hosting. I love them, until they continue their hard work and I 'll use them.

Very disappointed in the level of support I received to resolve an SSL certificate renewal. The wildcard SSL in question was set to auto-renew but is was not being applied. Customers to my website were receiving an insecure error.
Bluehost support's solution was to just wait it will apply eventually. Sounded like they didn't really know what was happening. So I waited 5 hours.
Still no new SSL cert. I called again. This time they said it was Comodo's fault and told me to call Comodo even though the SSL cert was automatically purchased on Bluehost site.
When I called Comodo they said they needed the Comodo order number. Well, I don't have the comodo order number because I purchase the SSL cert on Bluehost's site. Been on hold now for 25 minutes with Bluehost to try and get the Comodo order number because it was not on my Bluehost invoice for the SSL cert. Uggggg........

I have been with Bluehost for almost a half year. Several times my email has been down. Customer support at Bluehost is not very helpful.
In some cases I was given feedback that their servers were down for maintenance. Down for maintenance!?! Why would a emai hosting be down for maintenance during peek working hours in Eastern time?
The answer was that they have several customers on the west coast and in Australia. Last time I checked the majority of the working population is in the eastern part of North America. What a joke.
I am also continuing to have several issues with my email not being able to receive. In some cases it seems to think my inbox is full. Seems ridiculous when I don't even have 500 emails in my inbox. I will be switching soon.

BlueHost ranked as my number 1 web host. Because of their outstanding rating,
and BlueHost give you a long list of features and plans which is easy to use, Which suit every user 100%. According to my knowledge BlueHost host more than a 500,0000+ domains and manage more then 10,000+ of servers across many cities of 3+ countries and approximately, The last 30+ days BlueHost give an up-time of more then 99.00%.

Don't believe the hype. I've been with Bluehost for many years, and watched it get worse over time. It makes me sad, because they used to be very good back in the day, and I was happy with their service.
It's super slow now. Even if you install a clean empty WordPress, the page load times are awful. You run out of patience way before you get to set it up properly.
My bills kept getting bigger for no apparent reason, and even after an upgrade to the "performance cloud", my WordPress site didn't get any faster. They're only interested in sales, not so much their existing customers. I strongly recommend looking somewhere else for a fast reliable hosting.

reviews.review_title: Good
reviews.review_text:
Hostgator are actually good to my liking and I do say I enjoy their service at one of my client’s websites and blogs.
        I purchased a shared hosting for their company and over 3 years they have been having a good time with their blogs. All customer service is always active and ready to assist 24/7. What I value much about them is their free live chat customer service which is one way to resolve your complaints. So I don’t see any reason why people are rating them below their limits. I Love their service because is good

reviews.review_title: I have been using HostGator for years now
reviews.review_text: I started my account with HostGator when I still learning html/css and wanted to publish my first website I was proud of. I am still hosting to this day. Their support is very helpful, one time I was in need of assistance with a SSL certificate and the chat literally went on for over 2,5 hours. Only downside I can think of is that sometimes their live chat is super busy and it can take a while before you can connect. Also 2 times my domains did not register correctly. Other than that the best web host in my opinion.

reviews.review_title: No www?
reviews.review_text:
Tried to set up a simple WordPress site via this Cloud package and in all honesty I’m surprised at how much hard work it was.
        All of the automated emails seem to be for the old system as they don’t tie up with what actual happens in the customer portal. It also didn’t link the fact that I’d registered a domain at the same time so there were other emails about that.
        It then turns out that you can’t change the URL in the WordPress settings so you are stuck with http:// version, no www. Not a major issue in many ways but not mentioned anywhere and a bit of an odd restriction.
        Talked to the support team, one of whom advised me to uninstall WordPress and start over, the other of whom said it was all the same and it didn’t matter and insisted on calling me “bud”.
        Can’t tell you what the actual hosting is like unfortunately because I gave up and moved elsewhere.

reviews.review_title: Their Cloud hosting is surprisingly good
reviews.review_text:
I am not a very big fan of Hostgator. There are too many negative reviews about their poor speed and slow support on the internet.
          Even Hostingfacts does not recommend their regular shared hosting plans.
        
        But, their cloud hosting has been a pleasant surprise for me.
          Little to no uptime , fast speed and friendly support staff is something, due to which i have decided to stay with them even after 10 months. Otherwise, i would have transferred to Siteground ( I like it a lot ) at any point of time.
        
        Hostgator Cloud is different, it is better and deserves the crown for this drastic improvement.

reviews.review_title: Expensive if you want more than 1 site
reviews.review_text: You’re only allowed to have 1 domain with the WordPress cloud hosting starter plan. The renewal rate is $9.95 which is pretty expensive when you consider other services and other plans give you unlimited domains. If you avoid the wordpress plans and choose the baby cloud plan you get unlimited domains for $7.95 and $11.95 renewal. $2 more for unlimited domains. You should get a baby cloud discount instead.

reviews.review_title: Long time HostGator user
reviews.review_text: I have been a customer of hostgator for some time now. I have upgraded from Hatchling to Cloud Business. The speed of my 2 mb website has been good and all issues on our site have been handled professionally and pagespeed / onpage results are just fine.

reviews.review_title: Fast and reliable...
reviews.review_text:
I used your discount and signed up with them 3 months ago. So far, so good. Not as single problem. I used to use Site5, but I discontinued using them as I felt the uptime was too bad.
        Hence the reason I switched.
        Overall, HostGator Cloud is a great host.

reviews.review_title: Support is on the good side...
reviews.review_text:
I’ve been using hostgator for just under a month and today I received a “500 Error” and my site completely shut down. I called their tech line and they said I had exceeded my bandwidth. Not Cool!
        However, after I contacted the support they quickly fixed it.
        Hands down – their support is good.

reviews.review_title: So far all good.
reviews.review_text:
I signed up for HostGator cloud back in June. So far, everything is working properly.
        Uptime seems to be 100% and load times are much faster than my previous host (Site5).
        I haven’t had a chat with their support (yet), so I can’t rate this.

reviews.review_title: Great support
reviews.review_text:
I am quite new to the blogging world. When I finally have the courage to create my own, I chose HostGator due to the reviews on this site. Yep. HostingFacts.com helped me with choosing my host, and I am quite satisfied. One thing I liked about HostGator very much is the support. Being a new blogger, I am quite slow and still learning about it. HostGator is such a huge help.
        I recommend this to new bloggers, and although the price is higher than most hosts, this one is worth the money and will leave you satisfied.

reviews.review_title: Definitely worth it!
reviews.review_text:
I’ve started my blogging journey with the regular HostGator shared hosting. It worked great for me until my blog started getting high traffic. I’ve faced several downtimes on HostGator and moved to Bluehost shared hosting. My experience with Bluehost shared hosting wasn’t that good. And I decided to upgrade to Bluehost Managed WordPress Hosting. I didn’t find any difference. Believe me.
        I bought HostGator Cloud hosting on last black friday and I’m still using it. It’s far-far better than Bluehost or GoDaddy (I’ve used them both).
        So far, I haven’t faced any major downtimes with HG Cloud Hosting. Thumbs up for this!

reviews.review_title: Horrible company
reviews.review_text: I was a loyal client for years and they used to be awesome. Today I recommend to everyone they stay away. Their tech was bad and the support was worse.

reviews.review_title: Worst domainbuy services

I would give them 0 star if there was an option available. BTW, The service type below doesn't offer domain option.Less

Their website is terrible. I tried to cancel in December THE DAY MY CREDIT CARD WAS CHARGED and they did not let me cancel. They said I would receive a refund shortly and it was never processed. I called again in January to compla...Read More

They refunded only 2/3 of the renewal price and said I had to pay the last 1/3. Such a scam. Do NOT use them.Less
How is it with peer-to-peer file-sharing?

Hi Mike,
ExpressVPN works very well for torrenting –  and with no meaningful logs, it is verty safe. The only thing to be aware of is that ExpressVPN does not offer port forwarding (although since it does not use a NAT firewall) this should not be required anyway.

Hi Douglas,
In your travels scrutinizing VPN software, have you uncovered any reason why “Expressvpnd” would be hogging 98% of my CPU cycles even when ExpressVPN is not connected? Is it some kind of ‘helper’ app…? Better yet, do you suspect I can delete that damn thing without crippling the main application?

Hi Jay,
Hmm. I take it you are using ExpressVPN’s Linux client? After a little poking around it seems that Expressvpnd is  ExpressVPN’s Linux deamon, so you probably need it to run the main client. It should definitely not be using up 90% of your CPU, though! I would contact ExpresVPN’s support about this. If you are not using Linux, then something fishy is going on.

Thanks Douglas for sharing your knowledge about that. Something fishy then, as I’m using Mac OS (maybe by some intellectual interpretation, they see Mac OS as a flavor or linux). I will take your advice…GRAZIE

Hi Jay,
Well… macOS is based on Unix which is closely related to Linux, so it would have not surprised me to see the “Expressvpnd” file on a Mac. Because I am a pro, however, I decided to check! I installed ExpressVPN into a macOS VM, and can see no sign of it. The only ExpressVPN process running is “ExpressVPN”. This screenshot was taken with the ExpressVPN client running and connected. As you can see, it is using 0% CPU (and this is inside a VM on a low-end Macbook Air). So I would definitely contact ExpressVPN’s support over the issue.

Hey Douglas. I got the answer direct from the ExpressVPN people. Here’s what I did.
ExpressVPN customer support was, in the end, very precise, efficient, and well…savvy.
ExpressVPN support also supplied (true to their name) an express way to remove the existing program with one command line entered into the terminal. Neat…!
Then they simply had me upgrade from v-6.5 to v-6.7.1 and that too, was with one express URL and a new Authorization code. Most companies don’t do that. Translation: savvy customer support. 
Since I installed v-6.7.1, my CPU cycles for expressvpnd dropped from 98% to 0.1%. Uhhh….wow.
The only place what I am saying, compared with what you’re saying, differs, is that after my upgrade installation to v-6.7.1, my Activity Monitor shows three files running (couldn’t find a way to upload a png screenshot) with these %-age CPU cycles :
 ExpressVPN	                                0.4%	(main program)
 expressvpn-browser-helper	0.0	        (I installed their browser helper, so this is known)
 expressvpnd	                        0.3	        (I have no idea what this is or what it does)
So it’s a mystery why your Mac installation shows no expressvpnd file. Anybody there know what that’s about?
Incidentally, Douglas, unlike two people on this thread complaining about crashing or major loss of speed, my installation is rock-steady for hours and hours day after day. Reliability is one of the things I like most about ExpressVNP and IPVanish. I run both. They’re both great tools I’ve been using them for about a year or more.
The good news is ExpressVPN is running a small footprint.
LASTLY, I value your site highly for your rigorous checking, comparisons, and reviews. Without BestVPN I would not be using VPNs at all.
You converted me. Thanks for being there.

Hi Jay,
Thanks! I’m glad the issue is resolved and that ExpressVPN has done a good job at providing support. Since you installed the browser helper and I didn’t, I would hazard that the expressvpnd 0.3 process is somehow related to that (?).

For those like me who are technology challenged…If you are in the US and trying to increase your streaming using a VPN, I would search more “consumer reviews” rather than these tech sites.  A VPN will SLOW your streaming speed because of the encryptions.  I tried ExpressVPN since it had more supposed “customer service” and a longer trial period.  Waste of time.  Cancelled within a week.  It reduced my speed by 15 Mbps which was drastic considering it left me with an average of 5-7 Mbps using their best location.  You’d be better off spending the money to upgrade your router.

Hi Kerry,
A VPN will slow down your connection, which is why we perform extensive speed tests for our reviews. It is just a price you have to pay for the benefits of a VPN. As you see can from our extensible battery of scientific tests, however, ExpressVPN is one of the fastest services out there, and you shouldn’t really be suffering more than 10% or so speed drop when using it.

Constantly lost connection..support told be to reboot or reinstall which i did constantly..
had same problem on 4 different pcs..Would never use express vpn again.

Hi bob,
I can’t argue with the experience you have had, but must say that I am surprised. I, certainly, have never had any problems with ExpressVPN disconnecting regularly. I think you’re being a little paranoid, but that comes with the territory. The reason companies like ExpressVPN use virtual servers (typically in nearby countries) is for the very reason people use their services – security. If you’re in North Korea, for example, would you want to use a dodgy server that could have real security issues technically and physically, or set up a virtual server that’s located in a much more secure country but to all intents and purposes acts like a North Korean server for those wanting to use it within the country? It’s case of practicality and safety, of offering exactly what people are after in places like that – online security. Take note of where most of those virtual servers are located.

Hi Johnny,
The only VPN company I know of to own all its servers is VyprVPN, wich has other privacy issues of its own. Please see 5 Best No Logs VPNs for a more complete discussion on this issue, but it is not as bad as may at first seem. Any VPN provider worth its salt will full-disk encrypt all servers it rents, making their all data stored on them inaccessible to malicious actors (including the server owner). Traffic analysis could still be performed on incoming and outgoing connections, but the use of shared IPs not only makes this very difficult, but also makes it even harder to actually prove anything.

Hi Ronald,
Thanks for sharing your detailed thoughts with us. With regards to VPNs and compatibility with other security products, the problem usually comes down to firewalls. Security products can take it upon themselves to block the VPN connections, or the firewall rules used by the security product and the VPN can clash (VPNs often use firewalls to prevent DNS leaks). This is no fault of the VPN software, however.

Thanks Douglas. I wasn’t trying to imply VPN vendors are at fault because of incompatibility issues with security software only that VPN users should expect hassles like this to occur. (I had to abandon McAfee security and go to BitDefender with my last VPN in order to resolve an issue.) Note for other BitDefender users… BitDefender has a ‘general rule’ denying ‘incoming ICMP’ and ‘ICMPV6’ traffic that causes the speed test to error out. I am quite alright with disabling my firewall for a few minutes if I want to run this facility.

I’m just wondering why this review fails to mention ExpressVPN’s automatic “diagnostic sharing” option which shares your data with “third parties” – according to their terms. Maybe it’s because ExpressVPN is paying you for all the advertisements, pop-ups, and 1st place “best vpn” positioning… Do your research people, see the VPN WARNING List.

Hi Anonymous,
1. All reviews on BestVPN.com are impartial. As we make very clear to advertisers and business partners etc., the only way to get a good review on this website is to run a good VPN service. Even a cursory glance through our reviews should demonstrate that we can be very hard on VPN services if they are not up to scratch. 
2. I do a great deal of research when writing a VPN review. The relevant lines in the ExpressVPN ToS are (emphasis mine),
“Our software may send diagnostic data to a third party analytics provider for the purpose of identifying connection errors and possible bugs in our application. The information collected is generic in nature and does not contain personally identifying information.” 
Now, I’m sorry, but I do not consider sending anonymized connection logs to a third party to be a major problem. Yes, I know when comes to big data, that “anonymized or “psuedo-anonymised” logs are really no such thing, but assuming ExpressVPN removes the IP addresses of its users from the data, I do not think this presents a major danger. 
Of course, the fact that connection logs exist at all is a danger, and one that I have flagged up in the review.

Cons:  The use of the VPN will induce a reduction in internet speed. Even though this is inevitable with the use of a VPN and the accompanying encryption. Sometimes switching to a different server will improve the internet speed.
Maybe a con could be that the help articles are only available in English.

Overall:  It provides a safe environment for all your activities over the internet, even at locations where you cannot completely trust the internet connection itself, no matter if it is on your laptop or your smartphone. This gives a safe feeling and relieves you from working.

reviews.review_title: Amazing user interface
reviews.review_text:
Pros:  Fast connection, fast internet, great interface, super quick client support. I've bought it at a great price.

Cons:  There are some countries where the connection is pretty slow. If they would improve some of the south American, would be even greater

Overall:  I can watch US netflix! Also to visit some foreign sites i'm not able to do without a VPN. Fast connections to most of the locations

reviews.review_title: Safety & Security using open wifi access points
reviews.review_text:
Pros:  This gives me peace of mind when I am out and using WiFi points in coffee shops and in airports. While they can sell your internet history as easily as the internet service provider you use at home but I have a little more confidence in them since I'm paying for the service.

Cons:  Connecting to the VPN does slow your internet access down, getting around 100 MBps at home, and 45MBps when running through US VPN. For me, the items that I would use the VPN for are not big data consumers, like Banking and some work related access. Don't really see a need to access out of the country currently, I have heard of some people being able to access different content on Netflix, but not something I do. When watching Netflix or Hulu I'm not connecting to the VPN

reviews.review_title: Seamless VPN over multiple devices
reviews.review_text:
Pros:  All the security a VPN should offer, multiple countries and servers, and good integration across PC, Mac, android and ios.

Cons:  This is very challenging as to this point I have not found anything great. If I had to be picky I would say that I would like to be able to see all the servers together - when you select the obscurated server option you cannot see the others, so it forces you to switch back and forth.


        
            
              Vendor Response

              by NordVPN
                on September 14, 2017

              Andrew, thank you very much for your positive feedback. We are really happy that our services suits your needs!

reviews.review_text: When you trade in Binance, it "rounds off" the amounts you can trade. The leftover fractions stay behind, and recovering this dust is almost impossible. One way to do it would be again to deposit the coin in question and to juggle the amount deposited and the price, taking the fee into account, so as to leave nothing, or next to nothing, after a new transaction. Using BNB will reduce your fees, but it will not take care of this problem. Those bits add up, especially if you want to experiment with the odd exotic coin. I've learned my lesson and I'm staying away.
